See Also:
Constant Field Values

reverse_y

public boolean reverse_y
if true, display top to bottom instead of bottom to top on the Y axis. This is intended for games that want to offer a "reverse" view. This is only fully tested for simple square geometry games.

in addition to changing the piece position, it also changes the grid numbering and the mouse position encoding so spectators still see you pointing at the correct point.

reverse_x

public boolean reverse_x

swapXY

public boolean swapXY

Grid_Style

public java.lang.String[] Grid_Style
null, or an array of 3 strings, which determine the default number/letter style for grids.

Grid_Style[0] for left, Grid_Style[1] for top Grid_Style[2] for bottom

The strings should be "A" for letters,
"1" for numbers "2" for inverse numbers
or "A1" for both letters and numbers
or null if null, a default of {"1",null,"A"} will be used for diagonal_grid or a default of {null,"A1","A1"} for normal grid will be supplied.

isTorus

public boolean isTorus
if isTorus is true, the edges of the board will be connected to create an edge less board. I'm not sure if this makes sense for non-square boards. At present (7/2006) this is actually implemented for hex boards for use by Hive.

stepRow

public int stepRow()
return the increment needed to step from topRow() toward bottomRow() the recommended iterator for rows is
for(int row=topRow(),last=bottomRow(),stepRow=stepRow(); row-stepRow!=last; row += stepRow) {}

Returns:
+ - 1

stepColNum

public int stepColNum()
return the increment needed to step from leftCol() toward rightCol() the recommended iterator for rows is
int stepCol = stepCol();
for(char col=leftCol(),lastCol=rightCol(); (col-stepCol)!=lastCol; col += stepCol) {}

Returns:
an int

leftColNum

public int leftColNum()
return the column number that is being displayed visually at the left of the window considering the reverse_x and reverse_y switch. Shadows are normally cast toward the left, so drawing should proceed from left to right. However, some board perspectives may work better right to left.

Returns:
an integer

gridLeftColNum

public int gridLeftColNum()
same as leftColNum but for drawing the grid

public int rightColNum()

Returns:
an integer

topRowInColumn

public int topRowInColumn(char c)
return the visually top row in a column, considering the current board and the "reverse y" feature. This is intended to be used in drawBoardElements when a board should be drawn in top down (or bottom up) visual order to make overlapping pieces look right.

encodeCellPosition

public java.awt.Point encodeCellPosition(int x,
                                         int y,
                                         double cellsize)
find the closest cell and encode the x,y as a position relative to the cell grid. Normally the board has it's own mouse zone, so player views with boards in different positions will still give a fair approximation to the mouse position on the board.

Overrides:
encodeCellPosition in class BaseBoard
Returns:
a point
See Also:
decodeCellPosition(int, int, double)

decodeCellPosition

public java.awt.Point decodeCellPosition(int x,
                                         int y,
                                         double cellsize)
decode a cell position (encoded by encodeCellPosition(int, int, double)) to an x,y inside the board rectangle

Overrides:
decodeCellPosition in class BaseBoard
Returns:
a new "point" representing the mouse position
See Also:
BaseBoard.encodeCellPosition(int, int, double)

SetDisplayParameters

public void SetDisplayParameters(double scale,
                                 double yscale,
                                 double xoff,
                                 double yoff,
                                 double rot,
                                 double xperspec,
                                 double yperspec,
                                 double skew)
// this sets the basic parameters of the board, to determine the location of the cell grid points within the rectangle. For simple boards, this is just scale and offset. With all the parameters, it can be used to match the grid points to an arbitrary piece of artwork. Unfortunately these parameters are not independently adjustable, so to match artwork some experimentation is required to zero in on the desired grid.

Parameters:
scale - overall scale (normal 1.0)
yscale - y scale relative to overall scale (normal 1.0)
xoff - x offset in units of cells
yoff - y offset in units of cells
rot - rotation in degrees clockwise
xperspec - x forshortening as a function of y (0 is no effect)
yperspec - y forshortening as a function of y (0 is no effect)
skew - x multiply as a percentage of y

SetDisplayParameters

public void SetDisplayParameters(double scale,
                                 double yscale,
                                 double xoff,
                                 double yoff,
                                 double rot)
// this sets the basic parameters of the board, to determine the location of the cell grid points within the rectangle.

Parameters:
scale - overall scale (normal 1.0)
yscale - y scale relative to overall scale (normal 1.0)
xoff - x offset in units of cells
yoff - y offset in units of cells
rot - rotation in degrees clockwise

SetDisplayParameters

public void SetDisplayParameters(double[] LL,
                                 double[] LR,
                                 double[] UL,
                                 double[] UR)
The third method of setting display parameters requires mapping 4 points, and using strict linear interpolation to find the position of the rest of the points. This works well matching grid points to artwork, but only if you have a really orthographic projection.

Parameters:
LL -
LR -
UL -
UR -

SetDisplayRectangle

public void SetDisplayRectangle(java.awt.Rectangle r)
adjust the internal scaling parameters so the board displays inside the specified rectangle. This works by running a trial transformation of all the points on the board, then scaling the result to completely fill the rectangle if possible.

Overrides:
SetDisplayRectangle in class RBoard<CELLTYPE extends cell<CELLTYPE>>
Parameters:
r -

firstRowInColumn

public abstract int firstRowInColumn(char col)
return the first row in this column. Note that if the board supports a reverse-y option, it may be more useful to call topRowInColumn(char)

Parameters:
col -
Returns:
and integer

lastRowInColumn

public abstract int lastRowInColumn(char col)
return the last row in this column. Note that if the board supports a reverse-y option, it may be more useful to call bottomRowInColumn(char)

Parameters:
col -
Returns:
an integer

gridFirstRowInColumn

public int gridFirstRowInColumn(char col)
same as firstRowInColumn, but for drawing the grid. This is used by the Gounki board to extend the board by 2 rows.

Parameters:
col -
Returns:
the row number of the first row in this column

gridLastRowInColumn

public int gridLastRowInColumn(char col)
same as lastRowInColumn but for drawing the grid. This is used by the Gounki board to extend the board by 2 rows.

Parameters:
col -
Returns:
the row number of the last row in this column

emptyColumn

public java.awt.Point emptyColumn()
find an empty column. This is used for boards that are linked into a torus, so the best starting point may not be at A1

Returns:
a Point in an empty column

cellToXY

public java.awt.Point cellToXY(char thiscol,
                               int dispRow,
                               java.awt.Rectangle tbRect)
calculate an XY for col,row, wrapped by the board rectangle and spanning distances. this is used for torridal boards where the visual can wrap. It won't work for boards with perspective.

Parameters:
thiscol -
dispRow -
tbRect -
Returns:
a Point
